 Let me talk about a portion of the concept of "due process" for a moment. The judicially created doctrine of "substantive due process" holds that the 5th. Amendment guarantee of due process extends to cover all the individual rights in the BoR. In short, an arbitrary denial of any of these rights (free speech, the RKBA, freedom of religion, for example) means that the government violated that person's "substantive due process right." Where the federal government is involved the violation is referred to as a 5th. Amendment "substantive due process violation." And so although none of the rest of the rights in the BoR mention "due process" the concept still applies to them. 
 
 As an example, take the RKBA ban as applied to convicted felons. Two things are required for this law to survive a claim that it violates a person's right to "substantive due process." First, the felon's status must have occurred by "due process"-a legitimate conviction obtained by a constitutionally lawful trial process. Second, the law itself denying such felons the RKBA must meet due process review standards when considered under whatever "scrutiny" test SCOTUS ultimately adopts for infringements of the individual RKBA (I happen to favor the "strict scrutiny" test). 
 
 To bring it back to a discussion of "substantive due process" and the current McDonald case, remember that the individual rights in the BoR were always intended to be only restraints against the action of the federal government. The doctrine of "substantive due process" has taken these rights and has selectively "incorporated" them against the states to bar state action through the 14th. Amendment's "due process" clause. That is, the 14th. Amendment's "due process" clause means that a person has a substantive due process right not to have the state violate any of the rights in the BoR. Thus the states, for example, must respect the 1st. amendment rights of free speech, press, religion, assembly, etc. This is the argument in McDonald-whether the substantive due process guarantee in the 14th. Amendment also incorporates the 2nd. Amendment individual RKBA against the states. 
 Substantive due process also extends to find rights not expressly stated in the Constitution, like, for example, the right to vote, the right to privacy in general, and the right to abortion-bringing with it the consequent criticism of activist judges overruling the will of the people expressed by their legislators or the praise for judges standing up for individual liberty, depending on which side of the particular social issues involved you happen to favor. The best explanation of the extension of substantive dues process to find rights outside those listed in the BoR is found in a famous dissent by Justice Harlan, which has since become accepted as a majority SCOTUS doctrine (notice he mentions the RKBA):
 
 "[T]he full scope of the liberty guaranteed by the Due Process Clause cannot be found in or limited by the precise terms of the specific guarantees elsewhere provided in the Constitution. This "liberty" is not a series of isolated points pricked out in terms of the taking of property; the freedom of speech, press, and religion; the right to keep and bear arms; the freedom from unreasonable searches and seizures; and so on. It is a rational continuum which, broadly speaking, includes a freedom from all substantial arbitrary impositions and purposeless restraints...."
 
 Poe v. Ullman, 367 U.S. 497, 543 (1961) (Harlan, dissenting)
 
 Also note the Court is generally reluctant to recognize new rights not specifically enumerated in the constitution:
 
 "As a general matter, the Court has always been reluctant to expand the concept of substantive due process because guideposts for responsible decisionmaking in this unchartered area are scarce and open-ended. Regents of Univ. of Mich. v. Ewing, 474 U.S. 214, 225-226 (1985). The doctrine of judicial self-restraint requires us to exercise the utmost care whenever we are asked to break new ground in this field."
 
 Collins v. Harker Heights, 503 U.S. 115, 125 (1992)

The law recognizes the practical necessity for temporary protective orders in emergency situations being issued without giving the alleged abuser notice of the hearing or a right to be heard to contest the issuance of the order.
